Pakistan Has Stopped Receiving Postal Mails From India For The First Time Since 1947. Here's Why

Pakistan Has Stopped Receiving Postal Mails From India For The First Time Since 1947. Here's Why

For the first time in the tormentous history of India and Pakistan since the birth of two separate countries in August 1947, the exchange of letters through the postal system has become non-operational.

Even during the bloody days of partition and three wars that the two countries fought, the postal system remained operational, allowing the flow of letters between the countries that was divided at the end of the British Raj.

REPRESENTATIONAL IMAGE AFP

According to a report in The Indian Express, Pakistan stopped postal mail between the two countries in the wake of the abrogation of Article 370.

The report said that Pakistan has not accepted any consignment from India after August 27. The pile up has increased and therefore the postal authorities in India are putting the letters and consignments marked for Pakistan on hold.

The decision to curb the facilitation of postal services between the two countries is said to have been taken unilaterally by Pakistan and Indian authorities are unsure when this will end.

Representational image BCCL

Writing letters to their relatives in Pakistan is a common practice in Indian states of Punjab and Jammu and Kashmir. Besides, a lot of books and research-related publications are sent to Pakistan by leading Indian publishers.

Even Pakistani universities sometimes require research papers from India and the postal services is the normal route of facilitation for the same. Several people with relatives on the other side of the border were quoted as expressing their dissatisfaction.
